qas.question: What is the name for the kind of symbiosis in which one organism is seriously harmed and there is no affect on the other?
What kinds of amensalism are there?
When a large tree takes the resources a young tree needs, what type of amensalism is it?
What does the black walnut give out that kills plants?
What happens when a larger or stronger organism shares a resource with a smaller or weaker organism?
What happens when the sapling can take up rainwater and deplete some soil nutrients?
What happens when one organism is helped by another through a chemical secretion?
What secrets juglone, a substance which enhances many herbaceous plants within its root zone?
What are two types of antibiosis?

context: <a0_0><b5_0>Amensalism<b5_0/><a0_0/> is the type of relationship that exists where one species is inhibited or completely obliterated and one is unaffected. This type of symbiosis is relatively uncommon in rudimentary reference texts, but is omnipresent in the natural world.[citation needed] There are two types of <b8_0>amensalism, <a1_0><a2_0>competition<b8_0/><a2_0/> and antibiosis<a1_0/>. <b4_0>Competition<b4_0/> is where a larger or stronger organisms deprives a smaller or weaker one from a resource. <b6_0>Antibiosis<b6_0/> occurs when one organism is damaged or killed by another through a chemical secretion. An example of competition is a sapling growing under the shadow of a mature tree. The mature tree can begin to rob the sapling of necessary sunlight and, if the mature tree is very large, it can take up rainwater and deplete soil nutrients. Throughout the process the mature tree is unaffected. Indeed, if the sapling dies, the mature tree gains nutrients from the decaying sapling. Note that these nutrients become available because of the sapling's decomposition, rather than from the living sapling, which would be a case of parasitism.[citation needed] An example of antibiosis is Juglans nigra (<b7_0>black walnut<b7_0/>), secreting <a3_0>juglone<a3_0/>, a substance which destroys many herbaceous plants within its root zone.
